reporting-org.narrative: World Federalist Movement - Institute for Global Policy

title.narrative: Prevention Up Front Alliance

description.narrative: >>>Strategic Goal 1: Conflict Prevention --- Strengthening conflict . prevention mechanisms and infrastructures. >>>Strategic Goal 2: Reducing Impunity --- Providing access to effective justice and redress at national, regional, and international level >>>Strategic Goal 3: Increasing access, political space and opportunities for civil society to engage

The Alliance consists of the Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (GPPAC) network , and the two networks coordinated by the World Federalist Movement-Institute for Global Policy (WFM-IGP) – the Coalition for the International Criminal Court (CICC) and the International Coalition for the Responsibility to Protect (ICRtoP). Each of the networks in the alliance has a global Secretariat, as well as regional secretariats (GPPAC) and regional hubs (WFM-IGP) hosted by other CSOs. The global and regional secretariats/hubs play a convening role: connecting members with one another or with governmental and other actors where relevant at the regional and local levels

title.narrative: Prevention Up Front Alliance Annual Report 2016

title.narrative: Prevention Up Front Alliance Annual Report 2017

description.narrative: Prevention Up Front Alliance Annual Report 2017

title.narrative: 18th Session of the ICC Assembly of States Parties (ASP) held in The Hague from 2-6 December 2019

description.narrative: - Civil society representatives from more than 200 organisations and 55 countries—more than ever—were accredited to the ASP, opening up greater space for civil society demands and input at the ICC. In advance of the 18th ASP session, CICC members were informed of key ASP issues and capacitated/enabled to strategise on individual or joint advocacy - Increased awareness among ICC States Parties on the CICC Membership’s Priorities for ASP 2019 -Nearly a dozen CICC members addressed the ASP plenary during the General debate, including a CICC statement by the Acting Convenor. - During a plenary session on cooperation, four CICC members intervened, including one statement made on behalf of 29 NGOs, and 4 members also intervened during the plenary on the “ICC Review”. - The CICC also made the closing statement at the concluding session of ASP, reflecting on the outcomes of the annual session and underscoring its priorities, including the role of civil society in supporting the Court’s efforts in the global fight against impunity. -In the ASP Omnibus Resolution, “Strengthening the International Criminal Court and the Assembly of States Parties”, States again addressed threats directed at the ICC, its officials and its supporters, updating language from last year’s resolution: “The Assembly of States Parties reconfirms its unwavering support for the Court as an independent and impartial judicial institution, reiterates its commitment to uphold and defend the principles and values enshrined in the Rome Statute and to preserve its integrity undeterred by any threats against the Court, its officials and those cooperating with it, express concern over any measures against Court officials, and renews its resolve to stand united against impunity.” - The ASP also adopted a “Resolution on the review of the procedure for the nomination and election of Judges”, which amended the terms of reference of the Advisory Committee on Nominations, giving Committee members a stronger mandate and set of tools through which they can assess judicial candidates, and also amended the formal procedures on the nomination and election of judges, in an effort to strengthen the process by recalling states’ obligations under the Rome Statute.

title.narrative: DD3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.
Increased support for RS ratification by Ukrainian authorities

description.narrative: - Continuing from September) Revival of the Ratification of the RS campaign: Following the September letter to the Ukrainian President by the CICC and its members in Ukraine, the CICC published a press release, articles and re-launched the social media campaign calling for #RatifyRomeStatuteUA that led to increased awareness on the lack of ratification/challenges in Ukraine. - CICC members in Ukraine have organised a number of public events, press events and briefings for government officials and MPs in the reporting period, to inform on the RS and call for its ratification, and implementation.

title.narrative: DD3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.
High-Level Briefing on the occasion of the review of the procedure for the nomination and election of judges of the Assembly of States Parties of the ICC

description.narrative: - On 2 October, the CICC co-hosted and intervened in a “High-Level Briefing on the occasion of the review of the procedure for the nomination and election of judges of the Assembly of States Parties of the ICC” alongside the Permanent Mission of Costa Rica to the UN, briefing States Parties (SP) representatives on the role of civil society in ICC judicial elections, underscoring the importance of nominating highly-qualified individuals, and ensuring transparent and fair election processes.

title.narrative: DD4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
The ASP decided to establish an ICC Review process aimed at reviewing the Court’s performance

description.narrative: - Participating in the Hague Working Group meetings (an ASP subsidiary body) in which the ICC Review process, including a draft ASP resolution and the Terms of Reference for the group of independent experts, was discussed. Concretely, the CICC International Secretariat attended the following Hague Working Groups (HWG): o HWG8 on 15 October 2019 o HWG9 on 29 October 2019 o HWG10 on 5 November 2019 o HWG11 on 25 November 2019 - Drafting a CICC General Information guide on the ICC Review process and distributing it to all CICC members via email - Organizing a parallel session on “Civil society engagement and opportunities for strengthening the ICC and State Party support; evaluating the ‘ICC Review process’”, in the context of the CICC Global Strategy Meeting held on 1 December 2019. - The ASP decided to establish a group of independent experts to carry out the review of the Court’s functioning, with the aim of presenting concrete, achievable and actionable recommendations that could enhance the performance, efficiency and effectiveness of the Court and the Rome Statute System - The role of civil society in the ICC Review process was formally acknowledged by the ASP in its resolution on the ICC Review process (ICC-ASP/18/Res.7)  CICC members received information on the ICC Review process and on the main points of discussion for the 18th ASP session.

title.narrative: DD3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.
Supporting women's inclusion in peace-building and conflict prevention on the ground in conversation at UN 1325 week- October 24, 2018

description.narrative: Alliance members ICRtoP and GPPAC partnered with the Friedrich-Ebert-Stiftung New York Office to organize a panel discussion during the UN’s Women, Peace and Security Week in order to foster an exchange between female activists from around the world and promote women’s participation in the development of conflict prevention mechanisms. The event, entitled “Fostering inclusion to build resilient societies: How women peace-builders prevent conflicts and atrocities on the ground,” featured experienced women activists from around the world sharing their experiences of empowering women and advocating for meaningful inclusion in conflict prevention and mediation on the ground. Following guided discussion among panelists, audience members were given the opportunity to pose questions to experts, reflecting on progress made in the Women, Peace, and Security Agenda since the signing of UNSCR 1325 18 years ago, and the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead.

title.narrative: DD4

description.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

title.narrative: ICC Advocacy at the African Union summit, January 2017

description.narrative: As part of its advocacy efforts, the Coalition partnered with the Malian National Coalition in supporting the participation of the President of the Malian Coalition to the 28th ordinary session of the African Union Commission Assembly that took place in January 2017. The main objective of the mission was to build on the Coalition’s advocacy efforts to mobilize francophone African countries in preserving the integrity of the Rome Statute and to avoid the drafting and adoption of an anti-ICC resolution. While such a resolution was at the end adopted many states presented their reservations, which was an unprecedented fact since the resolutions and decisions of the African Union are taken by consensus with no reservations. The President of the Malian Coalition conducted interviews with the Ethiopian media, bilateral advocacy meetings with the delegations included Algeria, Benin, Côte d’Ivoire, Chad, Mali, South Africa, Swaziland. Attending side events was an opportunity for coalition and network-building in support for the Rome Statute.

title.narrative: visibility at conference
Assembly of States Parties (ASP) to the International Criminal Court (ICC), The Hague, November 2016

description.narrative: As part of its convening role of civil society, the Coalition for the International Criminal Court (CICC) continued to play a strategic role as a network platform not only by bringing the expertise from its members on the ground to the discussions of the Assembly of States Parties (ASP) but also by amplifying the voices of the local, regional level to the global level. The Coalition for the International Criminal Court services its membership by facilitating and overseeing the participation of its members and other NGOs at the 15th session of the ASP that took place in the Hague from November the 16th to November the 24th 2016.

title.narrative: conference
Assembly of States Parties (ASP) of the ICC, 4-14 December 2017, New York

description.narrative: As part of its convening role of civil society, the Coalition for the International Criminal Court continued to play a strategic role as a network platform not only by bringing the expertise from its members on the ground to the discussions of the Assembly of States Parties (ASP) but also by amplifying the voices of the local, regional level to the global level. The Coalition for the International Criminal Court services its membership by facilitating and overseeing the participation of its members and other NGOs

title.narrative: DD3
Raising awareness on the ICC Rome Statue to civil society, government and media in Ivory Coast

description.narrative: As part of its outreach and awareness-raising efforts, the Coalition’s Africa Regional Coordinator and the Deputy Executive Director participated to the 1st quarterly conference on the role of international justice organized by the National Coalition of Côte d'Ivoire. The 30 January – 3 February 2017 Conference focused on raising awareness on the Rome Statute as a mechanism for conflict prevention and peacebuilding. The targeted audience included civil society, government officials, media. Along sides of the Conference the President of the CDI National Coalition and the CICC staff members conducted advocacy meetings with the ministry of Justice (to advocate for implementation, take an ICC lens when becoming a member of the UNSC); the National Commission on human rights (to advocate for the Commission to observe and support the observance of International Justice Day). The mission included a preliminary meeting with the Center on human rights education for armed forces (Coordination Africaine des droits de l’homme pour les armées) to discuss possible future collaboration in organizing training seminars on RtoP, ICC related to preventing and ending impunity for sexual and gender-based crimes as well as on the protection of civilians agenda

title.narrative: n.a.
International Youth seminar on Federalism

description.narrative: As part of its youth outreach, WFM-IGP partners with the Spinelli Institute in organizing a yearly seminar targeting young civil society practitioners on federalism, regional and economic integration as mechanisms promoting peace and security, international law and human rights. The 2017 “Ventotene Seminar on Federalism” took place from 3-8 September 2017. The participants include NGO representatives promoting peace and human rights in the MENA region, and 4 youth participants from North America and Israel.

title.narrative: n/a
ICC-NGO roundtables, The Hague, May 2018

description.narrative: As part of the convening role of the Alliance, the CICC facilitated the annual ICC-NGO roundtables in The Hague from 14 to 18 May 2018, bringing together over 100 participants from international and national CSOs. The main aim of the roundtables is to take stock at current preliminary examinations and situations, strategize on how to strengthen the ICC as an institution by providing CSOs perspectives and expertise, thereby opening up space for civil society to engage with Court official and influence ICC policy. The roundtables culminated with a diplomatic briefing on May 18

title.narrative: #DD3
Cinema as a tool for social & cultural change - Training

description.narrative: CICC staff attended the 12th edition of the Summer School in Cinema Human Rights and Advocacy which consisted in a training initiative jointly developed by the European Inter-University Centre for Human Rights and Democratisation and the Cinema, Human Rights and Advocacy institution. The 7-day intense training was aimed at young professionals wishing to broaden their understanding on the connections between human rights, films, digital media and video advocacy to share ideas and to foster participatory and critical thinking on urgent human rights issues, debate with experts and filmmakers from all over the world during the 74th Venice international Film Festival and learn how to use films as a tool for social and cultural change.

title.narrative: n/a
Information email sent to all CICC members with general information on the ICC Review process on 5 November 2019 and CICC General Information guide on the ICC Review Process (Dated 5 November 2019)

description.narrative: Compiling all the relevant information on the ICC Review process since the formal discussions started in July 2019; Drafting a CICC General Information guide on the ICC Review process; Translating the CICC General Information guide into French and Spanish; and Sending the CICC General Information guide to all CICC members (sent on 5 November 2019).

title.narrative: DD5 # of CSOs with increased L&A capacities

The Ukrainian Rada (Parliament) Law Enforcement committee recommends MPs to adopt the IHL/ICL Implementing legislation ("On Amendments to Certain Legislative Acts of Ukraine on the Implementation of International Criminal and Humanitarian Law")

description.narrative: During an event organized by CICC members in February 2020, representatives of the Prosecutor General’s Office advocated for MPs to promptly adopt the legislation as an important tool. The Coalition conducted advocacy for an EU formal Demarche to Ukraine on universality and implementation of the RS, including the dialogue of informal contacts and outreach by EU MS, during the COJUR-ICC meetings and during the consultation organised by the EEAS ahead of the dialogue. In addition, the CICC conducted regular exchanges and calls with members in Ukraine to exchange information, intel, and draft an advocacy strategy.

title.narrative: DD4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
Regionally-focused side-events to enhance the dialogue among States and civil society from Africa, Asia-Pacific, Europe and Latin America & the Caribbean

description.narrative: During the ASP, the CICC organised four regionally-focused side-events to enhance the dialogue among States and civil society from Africa, Asia-Pacific, Europe and Latin America & the Caribbean- the majority co-sponsored by States. The events aimed at discussing current challenges facing the ICC and the Rome Statute system, and addressing ways in which the Court’s effectiveness and independence, and the integrity of its founding Statute can be strengthened in the above-mentioned regions and worldwide. Civil society representatives used these dedicated meetings to share their views and recommendations for States, the Court, international and regional organisations, and other.

title.narrative: DD3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.
Several EU and other European States express support for the work of the Court after the US statement threatening the ICC OTP staff in March 2020

description.narrative: During the EU COJUR-ICC meeting on 5 February 2020, the Coalition for the ICC coordinated and convened CICC members to discuss the statement and engaged in regular exchanges with the current EU presidency.

title.narrative: DD4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
Awareness raising workshop on women’s leadership in Assemblies in Côte d’Ivoire --- Abidjan, June 2018

description.narrative: Focusing on the Alliance’s cross-cutting issue of women’s leadership and role in mass atrocities prevention, conflict prevention and gender justice and in order to raise awareness of the necessary inclusion of women in the Parliamentary Assemblies in Côte d’Ivoire, WFM-IGP in partnership with le Réseau Paix et Sécurité des Femmes dans l’Espace CEDEAO, section Côte d’Ivoire (REPSFECO-CI) organized a 2-day workshop on 20-21 June, 2018 to increase the capacity of women’s and other civil society organizations and raise awareness on the need to advance the participation of women in the parliamentary assemblies. The 25 participants included: 4 opinion leaders, 2 religious leaders, 2 chiefs, 5 leaders from women’s CSOs 5 leaders from youth CSOs, and 7 leaders from political parties

title.narrative: #DD5
French translation and dissemination of manual on national mechanisms for genocide prevention - December 2018

description.narrative: Following the GAAMAC II Conference in Manila, Philippines in 2016 and the GAAMAC III Conference in Kampala, Uganda in 2018, the African Working Group of civil society organizations and other actors drafted a manual on the creation of national mechanisms for the prevention of genocide. This manual, originally written and disseminated in English, is being translated into French and Spanish. The translated manual will initially be disseminated in Africa and then in other regions, with the hope that the strategies described will be utilized by actors in various regional and national contexts to establish mechanisms for the prevention of genocide.

title.narrative: DD4

description.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs for, by, or with their membership/constituency

title.narrative: The Rome Report: documenting civil society's contribution to the drafting of the Rome Statute and creation of an ICC - December 2018

description.narrative: In December 2018 the Coalition for the International Criminal Court published the Rome Report, a publication chronicling the crucial contribution of civil society to the drafting of the Rome Statute 20 years ago. The Rome Report highlights the role civil society advocacy played in the creation of the first permanent international criminal court to hold individuals accountable for war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide.

title.narrative: DD4

description.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

title.narrative: “Taking Stock of the African Union Transitional Justice Policy One Year On” case study of Uganda with recommendations

description.narrative: In February 2020, WFM-IGP’s International Coalition for the Responsibility to Protect (ICRtoP) co-drafted a two page case study with ICRtoP member, Justice Access Point. WFM-IGP invited ICRtoP members to contribute to the lessons learned and recommendation document and publicized the document among ICRtoP members and social media. The ICRtoP Secretariat strengthened the co-drafter’s capacity to draft short advocacy briefs and ICRtoP members, partners, and followers gained a better understanding of the impact and future opportunities of the AU Transitional Justice Policy on the transitional justice landscape in Africa.

title.narrative: DD4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
Commemorating the Rome Statute 20th Anniversary at high-level event in New York, 17 July

description.narrative: In New York, on 17 July, the Coalition, together with Parliamentarians for Global Action (PGA), were proud civil society co-sponsors, along with the Permanent Missions of Argentina, Austria, Belgium, Costa Rica, Cyprus, Republic of Korea, Liechtenstein, Senegal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Switzerland, Uruguay, of the event, 20th anniversary of the Rome Statute: the need for universality and the International Criminal Court’s jurisdiction over the crime of aggression. The interactive panel discussion offered a unique high-level platform for States Parties and other international partners to project publicly a strong and compelling narrative about the ICC’s mission in today’s world. The event, which was well attended by both civil society and States, also marked the activation of the Court’s jurisdiction over the crime of aggression. For the first time since the post-WWII trials in Nuremburg and Tokyo, an international court will be able to hold leaders individually criminally responsible for waging aggressive war. 35 State representatives took the floor to voice their unwavering support for international justice and the significant role the Court has played in the global fight against impunity. A number of Ministers, including the Deputy Prime Minister of Slovakia, the Vice Minister of Norway, and Finland’s Minister of the Environment, attended and spoke on behalf of their countries, further demonstrating the commitment to the Rome Statute system that exists on all levels. This event was part of a year-long advocacy campaign conducted by the Coalition for the ICC to reengage states and other stakeholders in advancing international justice upon commemoration and reflection of the Rome Statute’s 20 years.

title.narrative: DD4
Training actors of the Malian government and criminal justice system in international judicial cooperation and the Rome Statute system - October 17-19, 2018

description.narrative: In October and November 2018, WFM-IGP organized trainings on the Rome Statute and International Judicial Cooperation for actors in the Malian criminal justice system, Malian government administrators, and deputies of the Malian government with Mama Koité Doumbia, the president of the Malian National Coalition for the ICC. Presentations were shared on the Rome Statute System, International Judicial Cooperation and the Principle of Complementarity, the Trust Fund for Victims, the Malian National Coalition for the ICC, and Sexual and Gender-Based Violence. These workshops provided an opportunity for civil society to influence high-level officials within the Malian government and build capacities for implementation of the Rome Statute. The trainings resulted in a list of recommendations made by the participants towards furthering cooperation and complementarity between the Malian State and the ICC and advancing public understanding of the Rome Statute.

title.narrative: DD3

description.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage

title.narrative: Global action against mass atrocity crimes Conference (GAAMAC) --- Kampala, May 2018

description.narrative: In an aim to strengthen the network’s advocacy capacity to implement early warning mechanisms, the ICRtoP participated in the 3rd Conference of GAAMAC that took place in Kampala, Uganda from 21 to 27 May, 2018. The Chair of ICRtoP, Secretariat staff, ICRtoP Steering Committee members and partners participated in different panels showcasing the work of ICRtoP in preventing mass atrocities and offering lessons-learned from national initiatives. ICRtoP partnered with its member in Uganda – HURINET (also CICC and CICC SC member) in convening the pre-GAAMAC CSOs symposium to discuss issues of prevention in depth, for example, the role of media, women, governments in preventing mass atrocities.

title.narrative: #DD5
Building the capacity of actors on the Responsibility to Protect in the MENA region - December 14-15, 2018

description.narrative: In order to build the capacities of actors to better operationalize RtoP and build on the Alliance’s network in the MENA region, the International Coalition for the Responsibility to Protect (ICRtoP) conducted trainings on atrocity prevention and RtoP in partnership with the Permanent Peace Movement (PPM) on the margins of the assembly of the regional configuration of the Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (MENA-PPAC) in Beirut, Lebanon in December 2018. By synergizing the training with the regional GPPAC network’s meeting, ICRtoP was able to access a large number of civil society organizations working across the themes of peacebuilding, human security, development, and conflict prevention in the region. Through these trainings, ICRtoP helped to build capacities for lobby and advocacy on the Responsibility to Protect and incorporate an atrocity prevention lens into CSO programming and advocacy across the MENA region.

title.narrative: DD5

description.narrative: # of CSOs with increased L&A capacities

title.narrative: Trainings on RtoP and early-warning mechanisms for CSOs in Côte d’Ivoire --- Abidjan, May 2018

description.narrative: In order to strengthen conflict prevention mechanisms on the ground, WFM-IGP partnered with WANEP Côte d’Ivoire (WANEP is the Africa regional focal point of GPPAC) in organizing 2 training events: one training, which took place on 7 May, with the goal of strengthening CSOs capacity (35 participants) to prevent conflicts and develop early warning mechanisms; and, the second training, on May 9, with the main objective to operationalize the National Early Warning System (NEWS) by strengthening the capacity of 31 experts monitoring the implementation and good functioning of the NEWs with a specific focus on violent extremism as a trigger mechanism. WFM-IGP’s regional focal point for Francophone Africa delivered two statements on behalf of WFM-IGP advocating for the effective implementation of the national early warning system and the participation of women in mass atrocities prevention

title.narrative: #DD5 #DD4
Training members of the Ivorian Armed Forces in International Humanitarian Law and the Rome Statute System - October 29-30, 2018

description.narrative: In partnership with the Coordination Africaine des Droits Humains pour les Armées (CADHA) WFM-IGP facilitated trainings for members of the Ivorian Armed Forces on International Humanitarian Law, the Code of Ethics and Military Deontology, and the Rome Statute System in Bouaké on October 29-30, 2018. These trainings, entitled “Human Rights and the 2020 Elections,” built up the capacities of the armed forces members in human rights law and the Rome Statute System to prevent violence around the upcoming Presidential elections in 2020. Ali Ouattara, WFM-IGP’s Regional Focal Point for Francophone Africa, presented training modules on the International Criminal Court and the prevention of torture. Additional presentations were given on Human Rights, Sexual and Gender-Based Violence, the Responsibility to Protect, the Code of Military Ethics, and International Humanitarian Law. Approximately 30 members of the armed forces attended each seminar. Following the presentations, participants were given time for discussion to share their experiences and discuss what they had learned.

title.narrative: #DD4
Training the Burundian National Coalition for the ICC - Conferences Trimestrielles --- Abidjan, April 2018

description.narrative: In the aim of strengthening the capacity for lobby and advocacy of CSOs in ICC situation and preliminary examinations countries, thereby reinforcing the Ending impunity Goal, WFM-IGP conducted a training on the Rome Statute and the ICC for the members of the Burundian National Coalition for the ICC. The main goal of the training was to increase the understanding of the RS and the ICC among members of the Burundian National Coalition and increase their capacity to carry-out activities and advocacy related to international justice in the context of increasingly shrinking space for civil society in Burundi. The trainings of the members of the Burundian Coalition took place in Abidjan (for security purposes) during the 24th and 25th of April. Part of the training included participation in the 15th session of the Conférences Trimestrielles, conducted by the Ivorian Coalition in partnership with WFM-IGP. The main outcomes were increased awareness and understanding of the ICC, especially as it related to the ongoing ICC investigation in Burundi, and strengthened capacities for civil society lobby and advocacy in the context of a repressive environment. One of the goals of the training was for the leadership and members of the Burundian Coalition to learn from the best practices and the leadership of The Ivorian Coalition. The trainings were conducted by members of the Ivorian Coalition, the field office of the ICC, WFM-IGP’s regional focal point for Francophone Africa, and via skype by WFM-IGP’s Deputy Executive Director. As a result of the training, the Burundian Coalition called for a meeting with WFM-IGP’s Regional Focal Point and the Office of the Registrar of the ICC to advocate for a more transparent process in electing Burundians to ICC posts with the consultation of the Burundian Coalition

title.narrative: #DD5 #DD3
Training the Guinean National Coalition for the ICC --- Conakry, April 2018

description.narrative: In the aim of strengthening the capacity for lobby and advocacy of CSOs in ICC situation and preliminary examinations countries, thereby reinforcing the Ending impunity Goal, WFM-IGP conducted a training on the Rome Statute and the ICC for the members of the Guinean National Coalition for the ICC. The main goal of the training was to increase the understanding of the RS and the ICC among members of the newly established Guinean National Coalition and increase their capacity to carry-out activities and advocacy related to international justice in the Guinean context. The trainings of the members of the Guinean Coalition took place in Conakry 4-5 April, the main outcome was increased awareness and understanding of the ICC and how it relates to a country under Preliminary Examination. As a result of this activity and the advocacy activities carried out by WFM-IGP’s Deputy executive director and WFM-IGP’s Regional Focal Point for Francophone Africa, the Guinean National Coalition launched a campaign to call for the opening of a trial to investigate the alleged crimes committed 28 September 2009

title.narrative: #DD5
The Federalist Debate

description.narrative: Joint publication with the Spinelli Institute - on current issues of global governance, European and Global Federalism

title.narrative: published
Advocacy on the Rome Statute and building the capacity and network of the CICC in Ukraine - May 15-17, 2018

description.narrative: Kiev, 15-17 May 2018 - The CICC Europe regional coordinator carried out an advocacy and network building mission to Kiev, Ukraine to attend a conference on fighting impunity for Sexual and gender-based violence in Ukraine, organized by CICC member Centre for Civil Liberties (CCL) and Zero Impunity. The mission provided for an opportunity to raise awareness on the gender provisions of the Rome Statute and to build capacity for the network in Ukraine.

title.narrative: DD4

description.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

title.narrative: On 26 November 2019, Kiribati acceded to the Rome Statute of the ICC

description.narrative: Kiribati will become the 123rd State Party to the treaty once the Statute enters into force on 1 February 2020. It will also become the 16th State Party among the Pacific island states. - The CICC advocated for Kiribati and other Pacific Island countries to be selected by the EU and its members states for the EU bi-annual demarches on universality of the RS, in 2019 and in previous years. - The CICC, together with member PGA, provided background information and regular updates on the status of the RS in the country and region.

title.narrative: DD2 # of laws, policies and norms/attitudes, blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development
La Haye Magazine - print publication

description.narrative: La Haye Magazine is edited, printed and published in Côte d'Ivoire, Africa, three times a year. Edition xxx copies, distribution in Africa (xxx) and a limited number through CICC offices in New York and The Hague. The publication's objective is to raise awareness and break the negative rhetoric and misunderstanding on international justice issues in Africa

title.narrative: n.a.
ICC video campaign launched at International Justice Day, 21 July

description.narrative: Leading to the commemoration of International Justice Day, in July 2017, the Coalition launched a campaign video to raise awareness on the Rome Statute and the International Criminal Court

title.narrative: n/a
Advocacy for Women Status - at the UN, New York

description.narrative: March 13 – 24, 2017 – As part of its network-building, and capacity development efforts to open spaces for civil society in intergovernmental processes, the Coalition for the ICC sponsored the participation of the President of the Malian National Coalition in her capacity as Chair of the women’s platform of Mali as mentor for two young women advocates from Mali to the 61st session of the Commission for the Status of Women that took place in New York. The Malian delegation attended the plenaries of the Commission as well as side events to raise-awareness and bring the context, experience from women in Mali. The main purpose of this mission was to give exposure of the two young women advocates to intergovernmental processes as well as to build network. As part of the activities of the President of the Malian Coalition, included advocacy meetings. Taking advantage of the presence of the President of the Malian National Coalition, the CICC organized a side-event to raise awareness on the ICC Trust Fund for Victims activities as a mechanism of reparative justice. The side event featured a presentation from the field missions in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda carried-out by the President of the Malian Coalition in her capacity as Africa Board member of the Trust Fund. The side-event targeted women’s groups who are not particularly involved in international justice issue to raise their understanding on IJ and ICC-related issues. It also offered an opportunity for network building amongst women’s groups

title.narrative: n.a.
Ensuring the inclusion and participation of civil society in the 17th Assembly of States Parties of the ICC - December 5-12, 2018

description.narrative: Members of the Coalition for the ICC (CICC) network, convened by PUF alliance partner, WFM-IGP, actively defended the cornerstone principles of the Rome Statute and worked to raise awareness among government stakeholders of their rights and obligations under the Statute, particularly in advance of and at the 17th session of the Assembly of States Parties (ASP), held in The Hague from 5 – 12 December. The CICC ensured that civil society members were present at every step of the ASP, monitoring sessions and interacting with delegates, in order to advocate for a fair, effective and independent ICC. During the General Debate, and during plenary segments – in particular during the discussion on the 20th anniversary of the Rome Statute on 7 December—the Coalition called on states to resolutely condemn all efforts to interfere in the Court’s investigations and prosecutions; all threats levied against the Court and its proponents; and the spread of misleading and false information about the Rome Statute system.

title.narrative: DD3

description.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.

title.narrative: The EU agrees to include a point on the ICC for the EU Ukraine Human Rights Dialogue, urging them to ratify and re-iterating the commitment made in the Association agreement - scheduled for March but cancelled as a result of COVID-19

description.narrative: Members of the Coalition for the ICC in Ukraine organised a number of public events, press events and briefings for government officials and MPs to inform on the RS and call for its ratification and implementation.

title.narrative: DD1 # of laws, policies and norms, implemented for sustainable and inclusive development.
Goal 2: Updated mandate for EUSR for Human Rights on 1 March 2019

description.narrative: On 1 March 2019 the European Union renewed the mandate of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights and, thanks to campaigning by civil society and especially the CICC Europe Regional Coordinator for the creation of an EUSR for International Humanitarian Law and International Justice, updated the mandate to include explicit reference to the EU decision on the ICC and international justice for the newly appointed Special Representative.

title.narrative: DD2: number of laws, policies, and norms/attitudes blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development
Goal 3: On 10-12 April 2019 the CICC facilitated the Asia-Pacific Regional Strategy Meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia which included 7 new civil society members from the region

description.narrative: On 10-12 April 2019, seven new or previously inactive members of the CICC participated in the Asia-Pacific Regional Strategy Meeting organized by the CICC in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The meeting brought together 27 national and international civil society organizations to discuss strategy and advocacy points for international justice in the region.

title.narrative: DD5

description.narrative: # of CSOs with increased L&A capacities

title.narrative: Goal 1: Panel discussion on holistic approaches to development and conflict prevention to ensure women's representation and access to justice on 12 March 2019

description.narrative: On 12 March 2019 ICRtoP, GPPAC, and Freidrich –Ebert-Stiftung came together to host a panel discussion on the sidelines of the 63rd Session of the Commission on the Status of Women addressing the importance of holistic approaches to development and conflict prevention in ensuring women’s representation and access to justice.

title.narrative: DD4: #of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
Goal 2: On 13 May 2019 the CICC facilitated a meeting of legal advisors from CSOs and States Parties on Court reform

description.narrative: On 13 May 2019 CICC facilitated a meeting of legal advisors from CSOs and States Parties which contributed to the Prosecutor selection process, advocating for states to keep this issue at the forefront and to nominate highly qualified candidates to serve on the Selection Committee. The conversation also focused on the independent panel of experts to review and assess the Court, a related process.

title.narrative: DD4

description.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

title.narrative: Goal 2: On 16 May 2019 the CICC and other CSOs sent a letter to ICC officials as a private communication on behalf of the undersigned CSOs

description.narrative: On 16 May 2019 the CICC signed onto a letter of civil society organizations calling on the ICC to take seriously calls for assessment and reform of the Court. As s result the Bureau and ASP are now moving forward with a reform project, which will ideally include a panel of independent experts to assess the Court. In mid-July, the ASP president and two vice presidents distributed a so-called 'matrix' of all the issues with the ICC, suggested forums for discussion (whether in the NYWG, amongst the Judiciary, in the ASP etc), proposed actions, and suggested timelines. They are fielding input from states and civil society until end of the month, with a view to present ways forward around the next Bureau meeting in September.

title.narrative: DD3

description.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage

title.narrative: Civil society organizations engage with the Group of Independent Experts conducting the Independent Expert Review (IER), in the context of the International Criminal Court (ICC) Review process

description.narrative: On 19 February 2020, WFM-IGP conducted an online meeting with members of the Coalition for the International Criminal Court (CICC) in preparation for the 24 February 2020 meeting between civil society organizations and the Group of Independent Experts, held at the seat of the ICC and open to civil society organizations around the world via remote connection. WFM-IGP facilitated the engagement through communications with the IER’s assistants in order to ensure the participation of as many NGOs as possible, both in person and remotely. The communications included works of coordination to gather information of interested NGOs, as well as, constantly transmitting information from the IER assistants to CICC members and vice-versa.

title.narrative: DD3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.
Goal 3: ICC-NGO Roundtables on 20-24 May 2019 create space for civil society advocacy on international justice

description.narrative: On 20-24 May 2019 over 110 representatives of civil society organizations around the world gathered for the annual ICC-NGO Roundtables in The Hague, organized by the CICC. This annual meeting provides an important opportunity for contact between civil society and Court officials, allowing CSOs to stay up to date on happenings in the Court, give voice to those affected by ongoing investigations or preliminary examinations and develop a strategy for advocacy.

title.narrative: DD3

description.narrative: of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.

title.narrative: Goal 1: On 22 May 2019 the ICRtoP facilitated a panel discussion on the differential effects of genocide based on gender

description.narrative: On 22 May 2019 ICRtoP facilitated a panel discussion entitled: Gender and Genocide: Engendering analysis for better prevention, accountability, and protection” on the sidelines of the UN Security Council debate on the Protection of Civilians in Armed Conflict. The panel featured experts in the field and addressed the differing ways in which genocide affects women and men in distinct ways.

title.narrative: DD4

description.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

title.narrative: - Goal 2: On 23 May 2019 the CICC Regional Coordinator for Europe participated in the 4th EU day Against Impunity and contributed recommendations to the Romanian presidency’s report

description.narrative: On 23 May 2019 the CICC Regional Coordinator for Europe served as a panelist at the 4th EU Day Against Impunity for genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes at Eurojust’s headquarters in The Hague, Netherlands and as a result several of the Coalition’s recommendations on the topic of “Joining forces in the fight against impunity – providing synergies between external and internal European dimensions” were included in the Romanian Presidency’s June 12 report of the event.

title.narrative: DD3

description.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.

title.narrative: Goal 1: On 25 June 2019 the ICRtoP organized civil society roundtables with newly-appointed Special Advisor on RtoP

description.narrative: On 25 June 2019 the ICRtoP facilitated an off-the-record meeting with newly appointed Special Advisor on the Responsibility to Protect Karen Smith and members of civil society. The roundtable discussion included a briefing by Ms. Smith and a period of question and answer.

title.narrative: DD3

description.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.

title.narrative: DD3: UN General Assembly holds first formal debate on RtoP since 2009

description.narrative: On 25 June and 2 July 2018, the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) held its first formal debate on the RtoP since 2009. Over the course of the debate, Member States reaffirmed their commitment to RtoP and its presence on the UNGA Agenda, in addition to supporting the Secretary-General’s focus on prevention and narrowing the gap between early warning and early action. ICRtoP Program Officer, Brittany Roser, attended the debate and the ICRtoP secretariat staff followed up with a report and infographic summarizing the debate. While civil society input was not incorporated in this new debate format, the inclusion of the norm on the formal GA agenda represents an important step forward, for both the mainstreaming of the RtoP throughout the UN system, and the domestication of the atrocity prevention at the national, regional, and international levels. The ICRtoP has been involved in advocacy for many years to make RtoP a formal agenda item in order to increase discussion of within and outside the UN framework and bring RtoP into regular focus in regional and national contexts as well.

title.narrative: DD5

description.narrative: advocacy efforts resulting in institutional change

comment.narrative: ICRtoP advocacy efforts in coordination with states made the inclusion of RtoP as a UNGA formal agenda item possible

title.narrative: The Coalition for the ICC urges the US Administration to cease its attacks against ICC staff members and their families

description.narrative: On 27 March 2020, on behalf of the CICC, WFM-IGP drafted and submitted a letter to the White House and the US State Department, urging President Trump to stop the US threats and sanctions policy against the ICC. The letter was addressed to President Trump with US Secretary of States, Michael R. Pompeo, in copy.

title.narrative: DD4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
Goal 2 - CICC issues press release on 30 September calling on Ukraine to Ratify Rome Statute

description.narrative: On 30 September 2019 the CICC published a press release on the need for Ukraine to join the ICC and make efforts to stop impunity domestically. The press release included input and quotes from civil society members in Ukraine advocating for ratification and the alignment of domestic legislation with the Rome Statute.

title.narrative: DD4

description.narrative: DD4: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

title.narrative: Coalition for the ICC expresses support for the Court in international media outlets amidst attacks by the US Administration in relation to the opening of an investigation in Afghanistan

description.narrative: On 5 March 2020, WFM-IGP drafted and published a press release in reaction to the opening of an investigation in the situation in Afghanistan by the ICC. The press release urged the US not to threaten the Court’s investigation into Afghanistan, following the Appeals Chamber decision, authorizing the ICC Prosecutor to initiate such an investigation.

title.narrative: DD4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
- Goal 2: On 6 June 2019 a draft bill for the harmonization of Ukrainian criminal law and the RS was accepted in Parliament

description.narrative: On 6 June 2019 in Kyiv, a draft bill for the harmonization of the criminal law of Ukraine with the provisions of international law, including the Rome Statute (draft bill 9438) was adopted by the Ukrainian Parliament (Rada) in first reading, after years of advocacy on the part of CICC members in Ukraine, and on time before the elections of 21 July so that it remains on the agenda of the new Parliament.

title.narrative: DD2

description.narrative: # of laws, policies and norms/attitudes, blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development

title.narrative: Goal 2: Civil society meets with non-cooperation focal points on 7 March 2019 and ICC fugitive Omar al-Bashir's plans to travel to Tunisia are cancelled

description.narrative: On 7 March 2019 the CICC convened a meeting with key civil society members and the newly appointed focal points on non-cooperation from Liechtenstein, Senegal, the Republic of Korea, Croatia, and Colombia to discuss ways to make states more aware of how they can impede or avoid instances of non-cooperation with the ICC. Thanks to these efforts states were alerted to ICC fugitive Omar al-Bashir’s plans to travel to Tunisia, which were subsequently cancelled.

title.narrative: DD2: # of laws, policies and norms/attitudes blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development
Presentation on the ICC Review process during the CICC Global Strategy Meeting on 1 Sunday 2019

description.narrative: Organizing a parallel session on “Civil society engagement and opportunities for strengthening the ICC and State Party support; evaluating the ‘ICC Review process’”, in the context of the CICC Global Strategy Meeting held on 1 December 2019.

title.narrative: DD5 # of CSOs with increased L&A capacities
Advocacy at the Organisation Internationale de la Francophonie, Paris

description.narrative: Paris, 3 February --- Strategic meeting with the expert on ICC at the Organization Internationale de la Francophonie in Paris

title.narrative: n.a.
The Coalition for the ICC coordinates and organizes engagements and meetings between civil society and relevant parties in regards to the upcoming ICC elections

description.narrative: The CICC organized a meeting between New York based representatives of civil society (PGA and OSJI) and three members of the Committee on the Election of the Prosecutor (CEP), including the Chair. The Coalition bilaterally met with Tunisia’s judicial candidate in regards to the CICC’s elections campaign. The CICC also participated in an informal meeting, organized by Human Rights Watch, with a member of the Panel of Experts to the Committee on the Election of the Prosecutor.

title.narrative: DD3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.
Raising awareness on the ICC Trust Fund for Victims activities as a mechanism of reparative justice --- UN, New York

description.narrative: The CICC organized a side-event to raise awareness on the ICC Trust Fund for Victims activities as a mechanism of reparative justice. The side event featured a presentation from the field missions in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda carried-out by the President of the Malian Coalition in her capacity as Africa Board member of the Trust Fund. The side-event targeted women’s groups who are not particularly involved in international justice issue to raise their understanding on IJ and ICC-related issues. It also offered an opportunity for network building amongst women’s groups

title.narrative: n.a.
Advocating for an independent and effective ICC at the 17th Assembly of States Parties - December 5-12, 2018

description.narrative: The Coalition advocated for states to commit to work together to oppose any and all efforts to undermine the Court’s work and its independence and in particular threats made against the ICC, its officials, and those cooperating with the Court; and to continue to support civil society engaged in international justice efforts, including by ensuring their protection as defenders of human rights and their access to debates and discussions focused on strengthening the Rome Statute system and bringing justice to victims around the world.

title.narrative: DD4

description.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

title.narrative: Facilitating access to civil society at the 17th Assembly of States Parties of the ICC - December 5-12, 2018

description.narrative: The Coalition facilitated access to the 17th Assembly of States Parties session for over 500 civil society representatives from 159 organizations around the world, the largest number yet, and held daily strategy meetings to coordinate advocacy efforts and keep members informed of new developments and upcoming meetings. The CICC also organized separate dialogues on the margins of the ASP between civil society and Court officials such as the President of the ASP, the President of the ICC, the ICC Prosecutor, the Registrar and the Board of the Trust Fund for Victims. These meetings gave members access to the leaders of the Court and its bodies to voice concerns, conduct advocacy and inquire about ongoing proceedings and policy.

title.narrative: DD5

description.narrative: # of CSOs with increased L&A capacities

title.narrative: The EU accepts the CICC/PGA recommendations for a number of demarches on universality towards third States that are part of the CICC’s list (confidential) of target countries for ratification and implementation of the RS

description.narrative: The Coalition for the ICC prepared a confidential list of suggestions for EU Demarches on universality and shared this list with the EEAS.

title.narrative: DD1 # of laws, policies and norms, implemented for sustainable and inclusive development.
The proposed EEAS/EC Action Plan for human rights includes a number of IJ/ICC related actions and points

description.narrative: The Coalition for the ICC prepared and utilized advocacy points during EEAS consultations on the Action Plan. This consisted of broad CSO consultation, specific IJ consultation with the EEAS, meeting with the EUSR office and the ICC focal point, and including ICC/IJ points in the Human Rights and Democracy Network (HRDN) advocacy and materials (to be continued in April and/or May).

title.narrative: DD4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
CICC launches campaign to appoint EU Special Representative on International Humanitarian Law and International Justice

description.narrative: The Coalition has joined forces with Human Rights Watch, the International Federation for Human Rights, No Peace Without Justice, Open Society Justice Initiative, Women’s Initiatives for Gender Justice and the World Federalist Movement-Institute for Global policy to campaign for the appointment of an EU Special Representative for International Humanitarian Law (IHL) and International Justice (IJ). The EU and its member states have a longstanding commitment to promote respect for human rights and IHL and to fight impunity for international crimes through criminal prosecutions. Translating these commitments into effective action needs to be a matter of urgent priority for the EU, in the face of an alarming commission of international crimes across the globe and weakened support for international justice. As part of this campaign, the CICC Regional Coordinator for Europe wrote a letter in August together with other CSOs addressed to Frederica Mogherini, High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security and Vice President of the European Commission, to call on her to swiftly establish an EUSR for IHL and IJ. Additionally, the Coalition has co-authored a backgrounder on the call for an EUSR and continued to raise awareness about the campaign through social media and the Global Justice News Center on its website.

title.narrative: DD4
Georgia nominates an ICC judicial candidate for the first time

description.narrative: The Georgian CICC, a member of the Coalition for the ICC, raised awareness and shared views and concerns regarding the domestic selection and nomination process, relayed by the CICC’s Regional Coordinator for Europe in social media. The GCICC also followed and published a number of statements on the nomination process in the country. In addition, the Coalition conducted regular exchanges and calls with CICC members in Georgia in order to disseminate information, intel, and draft an advocacy strategy.

title.narrative: DD3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.
CICC Steering Committee meeting, The Hague, June

description.narrative: The Hague, 12 June --- As part of its coalition-building efforts, the CICC held a retreat of its Steering Committee members on June 12 2017 to take stock at the current structure of the network, its membership and leadership. CICC Steering Committee member organizations present: - Amnesty International - Federation Internationale pour les Droits de l'Homme (FIDH) - Redress - Parliamentarians for Global Action (PGA) - among others

title.narrative: n.a.
ICC-CICC-NGO Strategic roundtable meetings, The Hague, June

description.narrative: The Hague, 13-16 June --- In order to strengthen the ICC mandate and performance so to ensure it is a fair, effective and independent institution, CICC as the main convenor of civil society working on international justice issues organizes strategic discussions with the Court. In this regard, the CICC and ICC held its 22nd strategic meeting ICC-NGOs and gathered up to 80 Civil society representatives to get updates on the status of the prosecutions, investigations, discuss how to improve victims outreach, victims and witnesses protection. During these roundtables, civil society also meets with the Trust Fund for Victims to get updates on its activities and strategize so to ensure that the Fund’s outreach to and redress programs for affected communities are locally grounded, effective and gender-inclusive.

title.narrative: n.a.
ICRtoP Steering Committee and UN General Assembly session on RtoP

description.narrative: The ICRtoP SC meeting took place 8 September 2017, following the General Assembly session on RtoP on September 6, 2017 and the meeting with the RtoP special adviser that took place on September 7th, 2017 – all meetings in New York.

title.narrative: attendance
Convening WFM Congress to change WFM policy, organization and governance structure, 10-14 July 2018

description.narrative: WFM-IGP convened its governing body of Congress, made up of non-profit member organizations, during the week of 9-12 July 2018 to discuss changes to the WFM organizational structure, the establishment of Transnational Working Groups, the composition of WFM committees for membership, policy review and statues, and the election of the new WFM Executive Committee (Board of Directors).

title.narrative: none
Deepening the understanding of the ICC interventions in Northern Uganda

description.narrative: WFM-IGP partnered with its CICC Ugandan member Platform for Social Justice (PSJ) to organize 1. an awareness-raising conference - “Deepening the understanding of the ICC interventions in Northern Uganda”, a two-prong community sensitization dialogue (6 April) 2. a commemoration event (19 May) to highlight achievements of the ICC in Northern Uganda, particularly in relation to the case of the “Prosecutor vs Dominic Ongwen”

title.narrative: n.a.

description.narrative: n.a.

title.narrative: Awareness-raising conferences on ICC in Africa

description.narrative: WFM-IGP strengthened its partnership with its CICC Ivorian National Coalition in an effort to reinforce its overall awareness-raising, outreach and communications and capacity building efforts in Africa through quarterly awareness-raising conferences Les Conférences trimestrielles

title.narrative: n.a.
Improving the culture of respect for human rights and international law for the Armed Forces Ivory Coast

description.narrative: With the aim to improve the culture of respect for human rights and support for international justice among members of the armed forces in Côte d’Ivoire and also in order to combat sexual violence committed by the armed forces in Côte d’Ivoire, WFM-IGP in partnership with La Coordination Africaine des Droits de l’Homme pour les Armées (CADHA) – The African Coordination for Human Rights Education for the Armed Forces –conducted trainings on the RS, the gender provisions of the RS, and international humanitarian law for members of the armed forces. It concerned 2 trainings - one in the 4th military region of Korhogo from 12-13 march 2018 and the other in the 2nd military region of Daloa from 15-16 March 2018. Sixty officers were trained in international humanitarian law, the responsibility to protect and UNSC1325 with a total of 93 participants: including authorities, press and trainers.

title.narrative: Training Sudanese refugee women in Uganda on access to justice

description.narrative: With the aim to strengthen civil society’s advocacy as activists in diaspora (and as refugees) and increase the awareness of South Sudan’s refugee’ rights in Uganda. In particular to influence policy and law making processes in order to strengthen women’s access to justice.. WFM-IGP’s Coalition for the ICC in partnership with Platform for social Justice has conducted a Paralegal training for 83 refugees from Southern Sudan on Gender Justice on 29-31 January, 2018 on the gender provisions of the Rome Statute and raising awareness on sexual and gender-based violence.

title.narrative: Human rights law trainings to young political leaders running for upcoming elections, Ivory Coast

description.narrative: With the aim to strengthen early warning mechanisms and reduce electoral violence, WFM-IGP in partnership with La Coalition de la société civile pour la paix et le développement démocratique en Côte d’Ivoire – Civil society coalition for peace and democratic development in Côte d’Ivoire has reinforced trained and reinforced the early warning and electoral monitoring committee as well as trained 21 young leaders of different political parties on, human rights, international humanitarian law including mechanisms to combat sexual and gender-based. The 21 young leaders of the region of Yamoussoukro were also initiated and trained on the code of conduct of political parties. The trainings took place 26 to 28 March 2018.

title.narrative: Sponsoring participants from Mali to the 62nd session of the UN Commission Status of Women, New York - March 12-23, 2018

description.narrative: With the aim to strengthen the knowledge on intergovernmental processes of young female activists in Mali, WFM-IGP has sponsored the participation of 3 young female activists, 2 senior activists from Mali (President of lead partner in Mali MUSONET) and Fiji (Executive Director of Femlink and GPPAC’s Chair) as well as a professor/trainer from Jaen University to the 62nd session of the Commission status of women – which took place in New York from March 12 to 23, 2018.

title.narrative: DD3

description.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.

title.narrative: Public awareness raising meetings in Zambia

description.narrative: Zambia, May --- WFM-IGP partnered with its CICC Zambian member The Southern African Centre for the Constructive Resolution of Disputes (SACCORD) to conduct public awareness meetings, hold public debates with key stakeholders during the month of May on the withdraw and lobby government to publicise a road map for the consultation process on the meaning of a withdrawal from the Rome Statute Treaty including the different stakeholders involved in order to promote and uphold people’s rights by providing basic information for independent decision making and so to enable citizens defend their decisions on a potential withdrawal from the RS Treaty. These consultations resulted in Increased public awareness on the ICC

title.narrative: n.a.
Goal 2: NGO/UN adviser meetings lead to TOR for ICC Prosecutor Election on 14 February 2019

description.narrative: o On 14 February 2019 the CICC and civil society members met with UN-based legal advisers to discuss the draft Terms of Reference for the committee on the election of the next ICC Prosecutor, resulting in the adoption of a terms of reference that clearly outlines a role for independent experts and civil society and ensures a balance of gender, geographical, and legal backgrounds of candidates throughout the process.

title.narrative: DD3: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage
Goal 1: Launching of policy note on experience of women peace-builders in conflict prevention on 8 March 2019

description.narrative: o On 8 March 2019 ICRtoP, GPPAC, and Freidrich-Ebert-Stiftung launched a policy note stemming from discussions during the UN 1325 week panel event addressing the role of women peacebuilders in preventing violent conflict and mass atrocities on the ground.

description.narrative: o The CICC assisted members in facilitating an international conference in Ukraine on RS ratification, during which CICC Regional Coordinator for Europe gave a speech on the importance of the EU in pushing for ratification in The Ukraine.

1 Women, Peace, and Security side event “Ensuring the Inclusion of Young Women in Conflict and Atrocity Prevention” (co-sponsored by GPPAC, other CSOs, and the Permanent Mission of Germany)

description.narrative: § Panelists’ voices were amplified by speaking at a side event § Attendees have increased understanding of the need to include young women in conflict and atrocity prevention discussions § Attendees have increased understanding of the successes, challenges, and recommendations to include young women in conflict and atrocity prevention discussions§ Co-drafted Concept Note with co-sponsors § Welcomed participants to the side event/Made opening remarks § Live tweeted from the event (awareness-raising)

1 training for 20+ MENA activists

description.narrative: § Participants have increased capacities to identify early warning signs of atrocities and early actions (by December 2019) § Participants have draft localized plans of action to build/strengthen their atrocity prevention programming (AM: I don’t know if they’ve used it yet b/c the training was so recent)§ Created training modules on early warning and early actions, including a hypothetical scenario to analyze § Co-facilitated MENA training with ICRtoP member/local partner

description.narrative: DD4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
